The clock ticks at a whole other rhythm on days when I work from home, writes Globe Journalist Dave McGinn.⁠
⁠
Talk to most people who are fortunate enough to work from home and two things are clear: They really, really enjoy it, and they’re worried the privilege will be yanked away by employers who want them visible at all times. But the reason those employees see remote work as such a benefit may surprise a lot of those bosses. It’s not about slacking off, it’s about autonomy.⁠
⁠
@brigidschulte, author of Overwhelmed: Work, Love, and Play When No One Has the Time, calls it “schedule control.”⁠
⁠
Read more about how its changing our relationship with work and free time at theglobeandmail.com.⁠
⁠
Illustration by Mollie Cronin (@art.brat.comics)⁠
⁠
#RemoteWork⁠
#ScheduleControl⁠
#WorkFromHome

Katie Telford has run Justin Trudeau’s office since the 2015 election that swept the Liberals into power. She’s one of the most powerful people in the country by virtue of the fact that her tight bond with the Prime Minister runs this government, and Canada at large right now.⁠
⁠
But now, as the polls clobber the Liberals and they can’t seem to shake a staggering inertia, Ms. Telford’s longevity is evidence of the depth of Mr. Trudeau’s reliance on her – not a sign that her clock is running down.⁠
⁠
At the very moment when it’s crucial to get some fresh perspective, the same qualities that make Mr. Trudeau and Ms. Telford so valuable to each other is precisely what might not be serving them well any more.⁠
⁠
Read more from Shannon Proudfoot's profile on Katie Telford at tgam.ca/telford.⁠
⁠
Photo by Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press⁠
⁠
#CdnPoli ⁠
#Trudeau ⁠
#Politics

As summer winds down, cozy up to fall with the best books, music, movies and more. From Taylor Swift's Eras Tour concert film to big theatre productions, the Globe's arts critics share what they can't wait to experience in the Fall Cultural Preview.⁠
⁠
Illustration by Sarah Farquhar/The Globe and Mail⁠
⁠
#artspreview #film #culture

Raymond Moriyama (@moriyamateshima) was one of the leading figures in a generation of architects whose work reshaped Canada’s built landscape and especially its public buildings. He died Sept. 1 at the age of 93.⁠
⁠
His origin story was as much a part of his work as his education. Born in Vancouver on Oct. 11, 1929, for years the federal government confined Mr. Moriyama’s family along with 22,000 other Japanese-Canadians, exiling them from their homes on the B.C. coast to old mining towns.⁠
⁠
Mr. Moriyama began his practice in 1958 with a set of ideals common among young architects: a commitment to public buildings and to exploring formal and technical innovation. His work was always shaped by specific narratives and concepts, elaborated with great care. These are some of those spaces. ⁠
⁠
Read more about his life on theglobeandmail.com.⁠
⁠
Photo 1 - Raymond Moriyama with a model of the Ontario Science Centre. John McNeill/The Globe and Mail⁠
Photo 2 - Inside the Toronto Reference Library. Fred Lum/The Globe and Mail⁠
Photo 3 - The Canadian War Museum in Ottawa. Tom Arban/Moriyama Teshima Architects⁠
Photo 4 - The Ontario Science Centre. Moriyama Teshima Architects⁠
Photo 5 - The Original Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre in Toronto. Originate Developments⁠
Photo 6 - Mr. Moriyama in 2010. Fred Lum/The Globe and Mail⁠
⁠
#RaymondMoriyama⁠
#Architecture⁠
#CanadianArchitecture

A rare, monstrous earthquake struck Morocco, sending people racing from their beds and into the streets. It toppled buildings in mountainous villages and ancient cities not built to withstand such force.⁠
⁠
More than 1,000 people were killed, and the toll was expected to rise as rescuers struggled Saturday to get through boulder-strewn roads to the remote areas hit hardest.⁠
⁠
The magnitude-6.8 quake, the biggest to hit the North African country in 120 years, sent people fleeing into darkened streets in terror and disbelief late Friday.⁠
⁠
Follow the link in our bio for our ongoing coverage of the disaster response in Morocco.⁠
⁠
Photos 1, 4: ABDELHAK BALHAKI/REUTERS⁠
Photos 2, 3, 5, 6: FADEL SENNA/AFP/GETTY IMAGES⁠
Photos 7-10: MOSA'AB ELSHAMY/THE ASSOCIATED PRESS ⁠
⁠
#Morocco ⁠
#Marrakesh⁠
#Earthquake

Journalist Peter C. Newman died early Thursday at age 94 of complications of Parkinson’s disease.⁠
⁠
Peter C. Newman spent decades documenting Canadian rogues and adventurers in big business and politics. He went from Czech refugee to magazine editor, historian and media maverick.⁠
⁠
An indefatigable editor-in-chief who briefly oversaw the Toronto Star and remade Maclean’s for the modern era, he also, over the course of more than two dozen books, pioneered a new genre of narrative business reportage for Canadian readers.⁠
⁠
In 1990, he was named a companion of the Order of Canada.⁠
⁠
Photo by James Lewcun/The Globe and Mail.⁠
⁠
Read the full obituary at theglobeandmail.com.⁠
⁠
#PeterCNewman

This summer, The Globe and Mail gave disposable cameras to kids to capture what they love about the season.⁠
⁠
What we got back is so joyful and instantly recognizable that it will split your face into an involuntary grin, even as your heart squeezes with deep envy.⁠
⁠
This is childhood when the days are long and the temperature high, photographed by William Olsen-Jeong (slide 1), Quinn, Abby and Nora Reynolds (slide 2), Videl Riley (slide 3) and Nahla and Massimo Alasaaed Osborne (slide 4).⁠
⁠
Swipe for a taste of summer and visit theglobeandmail.com for more photos.⁠
⁠
#SummerMemories⁠
#Film⁠
#KidPhotographer

As wildfires rage on across the country, thousands of people have been forced out of their homes in the Northwest Territories and British Columbia within the past week. Each one of those people have had to make life-changing decisions: Should you leave your home? What do you take with you? What might you never see again?⁠
⁠
Today on The Decibel, our daily news podcast, we hear those stories from Canadians on the move from fire-afflicted communities. Listen in at the link in bio.⁠
⁠
#Wildfires⁠
#Yellowknife⁠
#Kelowna

Spain won its first Women’s World Cup title less than a year after a player rebellion, holding off England 1-0 on Sunday after Olga Carmona’s first-half goal.⁠
⁠
The victory made La Roja the first team to hold the under-17, under-20 and senior world titles at the same time. Spain is the fifth winner in nine editions of the Women’s World Cup and joins Germany as the only two nations to win both the men’s and women’s tournament.⁠
⁠
At the final whistle the Spanish players piled on each other in front of their goal and were still dancing on the field until the trophy presentations.⁠
⁠
Follow the link in our bio for more.⁠
⁠
Photo by Hannah Mckay/Reuters⁠
⁠
#WorldCup #FIFA #WorldCupFInal⁠
#FIFAWorldCup #WomensWorldCup⁠
#Spain #LaRoja #WorldCup2023 #SpainvsEngland

If you spend any time on social media, you've probably noticed a lot of videos about "nature's Ozempic," aka the supplement berberine.⁠
⁠
Some influencers tout the supplement as a "miracle weight loss pill," but is it actually effective?⁠
⁠
Swipe through for a reality check on the hyped-up supplement and read the full story at the link in bio.

It all began with an innocuous roll call in Mr. W’s math class in September, 1971.⁠
⁠
“Rod G?” “Yeah.”⁠
⁠
“Brian R?” “Here.”⁠
⁠
“John O.” “Yeah. Here.”⁠
⁠
But then Mr. W called out: “Irving S?”⁠
⁠
A smile slowly crept onto John O’s face, his eyes slid furtively to similar faces in the classroom.⁠
⁠
“Here.”⁠
⁠
Irving Schwartz showed up on the official attendance ledger, wrote tests, had a picture and write-up among the grads in the yearbook. He was even toasted during the valedictory address of 1972.⁠
⁠
The only trouble is Irving Schwartz doesn’t exist. Never did.⁠
⁠
Read the First Person essay by Adriano Magnifico at the link in the bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration by Drew Shannon/The Globe and Mail⁠
⁠
#HighSchoolPrank⁠
#Prank⁠
#Essay

In PEI, the presence of Bliss and Wisdom, a Taiwan-based, China-linked Buddhist organization has sparked a fierce debate over land ownership on the island.⁠
⁠
The group, fuelled by tens of millions of dollars in international donations and led by a globe-trotting Chinese-Canadian woman, is linked to hundreds of land transactions in eastern PEI – an acquisition spree that has led to calls for a public inquiry.⁠
⁠
Bliss and Wisdom now has five affiliated campuses in PEI, with hundreds of students seeking enlightenment in the Buddhist tradition. Each year, more monks and nuns keep coming – and with them, more land sales linked to Bliss and Wisdom and its followers.⁠
⁠
Islanders complain that the Bliss and Wisdom-linked land purchases exploit loopholes in the legislation by dividing up transactions through a network of companies and individual followers.⁠
⁠
Read the full story at the link in bio.⁠
⁠
#PEI⁠
#BlissAndWisdom⁠
#RealEstate

On the 50th anniversary of hip hop, artists and historians are revisiting the massive impact women have had on the genre, fusing their sounds with a vision that distanced them from hip hop’s blatantly macho roots.⁠
⁠
A key part of their success was fashioning iconic looks and styles. American music critic and author Craig Seymour views the outfits worn by female hip-hoppers in the 1980s as direct responses to the male-dominated environment they were working in. Resistance was considered something that could be worn on the sleeve and expressed through clothing in an effort to dismantle sexist archetypes.⁠
⁠
“Hip hop was and still is driven by women who constantly reframe the game through style,” said Canada’s godmother of rap, @michiebadgyalmee. ⁠
⁠
From @saltnpepaofficial to @nickiminaj, we take a look at the signature styles and influences of women in hip hop. Read more at the link in bio.⁠
⁠
Photo 1: Lil' Kim, 1997 (Kmazur/WireImage via Getty Images)⁠
2: Michie Mee, 1990 (Al Pereira/Getty Images)⁠
3: MC Sha-Rock, centre, of Funky 4 + 1, 1981 (NBC/Getty Images)⁠
4: Missy Elliot, 2002 (Lucy Nicholson/AP Photo)⁠
5: Salt-N-Pepa, 1988 (Michael Ochs archives/Getty Images)⁠
6: Nicki Minaj, 2012 (Danny E. Martindale/Getty Images)⁠
7: Megan Thee Stallion, 2023 (Emma McIntyre/Getty Images)⁠
⁠
#HipHop⁠
#LilKim⁠
#MissyElliot

The fast-spreading EG.5 variant, first detected in February, has been behind upticks in the coronavirus across North America, and also has been detected in China, South Korea and Japan, among other countries. On August 9, the World Health Organization classified it as a “variant of interest.”⁠
⁠
It's been nicknamed “Eris” on social media by experts and scientists, to follow the Greek name classification of other variants, but the name is not officially used by WHO.⁠
⁠
Officials say that symptoms of the EG.5 have been consistent with general COVID-19 symptoms, which include sore throat, fever or chills, runny nose, shortness of breath, muscle or body aches, headaches or new loss of smell or taste.⁠
⁠
Read more about this new variant, including whether or not boosters will be effective against it, at the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
#COVID19⁠
#NewCovidVariant⁠
#PublicHealth

On Friday, the Jays signed a one-day contract with Jose Bautista. On Saturday, he will retire a Toronto Blue Jay.⁠
⁠
This was news to a lot of people who thought Bautista retired years ago, writes Cathal Kelly. That’s usually how it works when you don’t play baseball any more – you are retired from it.⁠
⁠
When people think of Bautista now, they remember the bat flip. Kawhi Leonard aside, it is the high-water mark of Toronto sports in this century. Which, when you think about it, is not something you want to go around shouting about.⁠
⁠
Seeing him now isn’t celebratory. It’s wistful. It conjures a long series of what ifs?⁠
⁠
Read more from Cathal Kelly and the legacy of Toronto sports at the link in our bio. Photos by Chris Young/The Canadian Press.⁠
⁠
#JoseBautista⁠
#BlueJays⁠
#TorontoBlueJays

At only 15 years old, Teaghan Bertamini is one of the few girls excelling at bull riding - one of the most dangerous sports in the world.⁠
⁠
A busy kid, she plays club basketball and hops on bulls two or three times per weekend. When she can, she polishes her riding form on a home-made bucking contraption fashioned out of a barrel by her father.⁠
⁠
Her goal is to qualify for the Junior World Finals in Las Vegas in December, which is within reach, given that she’s placed the top bull-riding division on the Crooked Horn Canadian Junior Rodeo Association for much of the season.⁠
⁠
She would also love to compete in the Canadian high school rodeo this August in Brandon, Man., but organizers adhere to American high-school guidelines stipulating that rough-stock events – bull riding, saddle bronc, bareback – are open to “boys only.”⁠
⁠
Swipe to see her in action, and visit the link in our bio for more photos and the full story.⁠
⁠
Story and photos by Leah Hennel (@leahhennelphoto)⁠
⁠
#BullRiding⁠
#Rodeo⁠
#BullRider

Guitarist, songwriter and singer Robbie Robertson, who led the Canadian-American group The Band, has died at the age of 80, his manager said on Wednesday.⁠
⁠
The Toronto-born musician spent part of his childhood in Six Nations Indian Reserve in southwestern Ontario, which had an enormous influence on him and his music.⁠
⁠
The Band was one of the biggest rock groups of the 1960s and '70s, and their 1976 farewell concert in San Francisco was the basis of Martin Scorsese’s 1978 movie “The Last Waltz.”⁠
⁠
Robertson died in Los Angeles surrounded by his family after a long illness, according to his manager's statement. The family asked that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Six Nations of the Grand River to support a new Woodland Cultural Center.⁠
⁠
#RIP⁠
#RobbieRobertson⁠
#TheBand
